I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) Country Strategy and Program (CSP) Update for 
India for 2002 included support for governance and public resource management reforms in the 
state of Assam. ADB’s India CSP 2003–2006, approved by ADB’s Board of Directors on 1 May 
2003, reconfirms this support. The Assam government asked ADB for technical assistance (TA) 
to  study  ways  to  prioritize  and  strategically  plan  a  sustainable  and  time-bound  fiscal 
consolidation  program  of  revenue,  expenditure  and  debt  management,  and  restructuring 
reforms  together  with  a  complementary  governance  program  of  public  administration 
restructuring,  public  enterprise  restructuring,  and  enhanced  public  service  delivery  and 
decentralization reforms. The Assam government also requested ADB TA to raise the state’s 
capacity to implement the reform program. 
 
2.  The TA is part of ADB’s support to prepare and implement the Assam governance and 
public resource management program loan, which is envisaged for 2004. A fact-finding mission 
visited Guwahati in May 2003 and reached an understanding with the Assam government on 
the  purpose  and  output,  methodology,  key  activities,  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan, 
implementation arrangements, and terms of reference of the TA.1 The TA framework is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.   As a consequence of prolonged political disturbances, Assam has progressively fallen 
behind the rest of the country in economic development. During planned economic development 
from 1951 to the 1970s, Assam grew at rates comparable to the rest of the country but has 
since lagged behind. While India grew by 5.4% during FY1980–1990, Assam grew at 3.3%. The 
gap widened further during FY1991–1996, with India’s growth at 7.3%, and Assam’s at only 3%. 
Poverty incidence declined from 40.86% in 1993-1994 to 36.00% in 1999–2000 in Assam, but 
dropped from 35.97% to 26.10%, almost 10 percentage points, in India as a whole. However, 
since the numbers for 1993-1994 and 1999-2000 are not fully comparable, the extent of decline 
in poverty incidence in Assam remains unclear. Assam’s infrastructure development index is 
only 72.7 compared to the national base of 100.  
 
4.   Reviving growth and accelerating poverty reduction in a service sector- and government-
dominated economy is a major challenge given the Assam government’s severe fiscal crisis. 
The fiscal deficit rose steadily from 4.9% of gross state domestic product (GSDP) in FY1990 to 
6.7% in FY2002. Even more disturbing is the high share of revenue deficit, which accounts for 
almost 58% of the total fiscal deficit in FY1999–2001.2 Thus, the large fiscal deficit is mainly 
used to finance revenue (current) expenditure rather than create capital assets. The deficit, in 
turn, adds to the stock of public debt.3 Public debt as a proportion of GSDP is steadily growing—
from 35.2% in FY1999, 38.0% in FY2000, and 40.5% in FY2001. Fiscal consolidation is needed 
if the Assam government is to (i) maintain and improve the state’s existing social and physical 
infrastructure, (ii) enhance equitable access and quality of publicly provided education and 
health services, (iii) prevent the further deterioration of existing physical infrastructure as well as 
other key public services, and (iv) promote economic growth and create jobs.

2     
 
5.   The Assam government has thus initiated a number of measures culminating in a 
memorandum  of  understanding  (MOU)  with  the  national  Government  on  the  Medium-Term 
Fiscal Reform Program (MTFRP): 2000–2001 to 2004–20054 and the commissioning of the 
Assam Administrative Reforms Commission report of 22 April 2003. The commission raised not 
only enhancement of government employee efficiency and productivity and rationalization of 
Assam government departments but also other important public administration issues such as 
the need to enhance government responsiveness. It may hinge on public-private interface 
mechanisms, including timely redress of public grievances, which reinforces accountability and 
avoids an adversarial and often dilatory litigation system. Administrative processes and systems 
will have to be reviewed. 
 
6.   The state has 48 public sector enterprises, including Assam State Electricity Board 
(ASEB)  and  Assam  State  Transport  Corporation  (ASTC),  which  account  for  76%  of  total 
investment in public sector enterprises. Instead of providing significant non-tax revenues to the 
state exchequer, all the enterprises together are incurring net annual losses of about $100 
million (Rs5.1 billion) per year, equivalent to 35% of the Assam government’s FY2001 fiscal 
deficit. Some enterprises are not even able to pay their employees’ salaries, creating a potential 
contingent liability for the Assam government budget. Building on the review work of the Assam 
government’s Department of Public Enterprises and the restructuring of enterprises such as 
ASTC, an independent, careful review of these enterprises5 is needed to determine which 
should be shut down, privatized, or restructured. Recommendations need to be in line with the 
MTFRP MOU, the policy of the Tenth Five-Year Plan (FY2003-2007) to reduce the role of 
government in production of goods and services, and a cost-benefit analysis of different options 
such as introducing a voluntary retirement scheme for employees of public sector enterprises 
that require closure or restructuring. 
 
7.   As  an  essential  complement  to  the  reform  and  restructuring  programs  in  Assam 
government departments and state public enterprises, governance reforms need to help refocus 
and restructure the Assam government toward participatory development to promote economic 
growth and employment through cost-effective decentralized service delivery. 
 
8.   Under the Assam Panchayat Act of 1994, 6 as many as 29 subjects have been notified 
for devolution to local governments. Building on the recently concluded panchayat elections and 
the Assam government’s amendment to the Municipal Administration Act providing for elected 
urban  local  bodies,  governance  reforms  need  to  foster  fiscal  devolution7  to  enable  the 
introduction  of  decentralized  and  participatory  management  of  public  services  such  as 
education, health, water supply, and other public services to ensure greater transparency and 
accountability of service providers to beneficiaries. 
 
9.  Taking account of the need for administrative support for decentralized service delivery 
under the aegis of the panchayat institutions and local bodies, and the potential for buoyancy of 
decentralized land revenues and property taxes, governance reforms must assess options 
based on cost-benefit analyses of rationalization of district administration, including land-titling 
reforms.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
10.  The objective of the TA is to improve  and accelerate development management in 
Assam against the background of the MTFRP MOU by helping the Assam government design 
and sequence priority public resource management and governance reforms, and strengthen its  
implementation capacity to implement them. The TA will focus on (i) fiscal reforms to improve 
resource  mobilization,  (ii)  public  expenditure  management  reforms  to  strengthen  fiscal 
discipline,  improve  resource  allocation,  and  enable  better  operational  management,  (iii) 
improved  debt  management  and  fiscal  responsibility  and  budget  management,  and  (iv) 
governance and public management reforms to enhance cost-effective, sustainable, and quality 
public  services  through  decentralized  delivery  and  accountable,  focused,  and  responsive 
government and public sector enterprises limited to an appropriate role. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA will be implemented under the following four components: 
 
 (i) Fiscal reforms (revenues). The TA will help (a) strengthen implementation of the 
subnational value-added tax (VAT), as well as improve mobilization of other tax and nontax 
revenues, and (b) strengthen local-body and devolved finances. 
 
(ii) Fiscal reforms (public expenditure management). The TA will include (a) a critical 
review of intersector and intrasector budget allocations under a public expenditure review to 
determine the degree to which they support state social and economic development objectives, 
an adequate level of operation and maintenance for existing infrastructure, and decentralized 
cost recovery, (b) development of departmental medium-term expenditure plans based on such 
review, reflecting resource allocation consistent with state annual plan and sectoral policy 
objectives (such as universal literacy and primary health coverage targets), and devolution of 
financial  autonomy  commensurate  with  devolved  responsibilities,  and  (c)  development  of 
appropriate performance targets under a state medium-term expenditure framework, based on 
such  departmental  plans,  integrated  into  a  fiscal  responsibility  and  budget  management 
framework. 
 
  (iii)  Fiscal  reforms  (debt  and  fiscal  responsibility).  The  TA  will  include  (a) 
confirmation  of  the  continuing  validity  of  MTFRP  macroeconomic  assumptions  and  fiscal 
performance  targets,8  (b)  establishment  of  an  overall  state  debt  management  policy,  (c) 
evaluation  of  debt-restructuring  options,  (d)  evaluation  of  fiscal  implications  of  contingent 
liabilities (state guarantees, pensions, etc.), and (e) integration of agreed-on macroeconomic 
assumptions and performance targets into an appropriately sequenced fiscal responsibility and 
budget management framework. In addition to defining the macroeconomic assumptions and 
the timing and identification of appropriate performance targets for structural changes in the 
fiscal system under a fiscal responsibility framework, the TA will also support the monitoring of 
such performance targets and accompanying institutional strengthening and capacity building. 
These will include workshop sessions for revenue, expenditure and debt management policy, 
and administration as well as capacity-building seminar sessions where staff from other state

governments can share their experience in public finance and governance reforms. Capacity will 
also be built by establishing and strengthening a monitoring unit within the state Finance 
Department. 
 
(iv)  Governance  and  public  management  reforms.  The  TA  will  support  (a) 
development  of  a  state  governance  assessment  and  strategy,  including  sequencing  and 
balancing of public administration and public enterprise restructuring reform with devolution of 
public services; (b) critical review, evaluation, and defined time-bound strategy and action plan 
for public administration reforms based on an expenditure and functional review of the civil 
service, including public expenditure tracking surveys; and (c) critical review, evaluation, and 
time-bound  strategy  and  action  plan  for  public  sector  enterprise  restructuring  reforms, 
devolution of public services,9 and district administration restructuring.10 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
12.  The TA is estimated at $875,000 equivalent, of which $515,900 is the foreign exchange 
cost and $359,100 equivalent the local currency cost. The entire foreign exchange cost, and 
$184,100  equivalent  of  the  local  currency  cost  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the 
Government of the United Kingdom. The Assam government will provide $175,000 equivalent to 
finance part of the local currency costs to cover counterpart staff, office accommodation and 
office supplies, transport, and other expenses such as for in-country study facilitation and 
workshops. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The state Finance Department will be the executing agency for the TA. The state 
Finance Department will be supported by a TA implementing unit (TIU) and will appoint a 
commissioner and secretary of finance as TIU director. The state Finance Department will 
provide office space, furniture, equipment, and counterpart staff for TA consultants, who will 
receive operational advice and guidance from the TIU director. The Assam government will set 
up a steering committee on governance and public resource management reforms for the TA, 
chaired by the chief secretary, with the additional chief secretary responsible for finance as the 
deputy chairman. Members will include commissioners; secretaries of the Finance Department, 
Planning and Development Department, and Administrative Reforms/Personnel Department, 
and  Department  of  Public  Enterprises;  and  representatives  of  key  line  departments.  The 
steering committee will be responsible for TA coordination, progress reports to be submitted at 
least quarterly to the national and Assam governments and ADB, and resolution of any issues 
that may arise. 
 
14.  All procurement of equipment will be undertaken in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
for Procurement. 
 
15.  ADB will engage a team of consultants to execute the TA: international consultants will 
work for 19.5 person-months, and domestic consultants, 27.5 person-months. The consultants 
will have experience and expertise in public finance, VAT and tax administration and legislation, 
public expenditure review and management, public administration and public sector enterprise 
restructuring,  utility  pricing,  sectoral user fees and cost recovery, fiscal and administrative

sectors. 
10 Restructuring of district administration will include development administration and land-titling reforms.

5 
decentralization, performance accountability and land titling, settlement, and revenue. A debt 
management  and  restructuring  specialist  will  be  selected  and  engaged  as  an  individual 
international consultant in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. A firm 
of consultants will be selected and engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB on the engagement of domestic 
consultants. The simplified technical proposal procedure and quality-and-cost-based selection 
will be used to select the consulting firm. The outline terms of reference of the consultants are in 
Appendix 3. A summary initial poverty and social analysis report is in Appendix 4. 
 
16.  The consultants will prepare an inception report, including a time-bound work plan for TA 
implementation, within 4 weeks of the start of consulting services. An interim report will be 
submitted within 4 months from the start of consulting services. A draft final report will be 
submitted 4 weeks before the end of consulting services, to be discussed in a meeting of the 
consultants,  national  and  Assam  governments,  and  ADB  before  being  finalized  by  the 
consultants. The TA will be implemented in 8 months. It is expected to start in October 2003 and 
be completed by June 2004. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 to the Government 
of India to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of the United Kingdom for Preparing 
the Assam Governance and Public Resource Management Program, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Individual International Consultant 
 
a.  Debt Management and Restructuring Specialist (2.5 person-months) 
 
1.  The consultant will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Review the profile of state debt, including contingent liabilities and ways 
and  means  to  retire  high-cost  central  loans  through  fresh  market 
borrowings. 
(ii)  Recommend options for further restructuring, especially with reference to 
the contingent liabilities arising from government guarantees, and help 
the Assam government negotiate with banks and financial institutions for 
one-time settlements. 
(iii)  Prepare a policy and manual for efficient debt management, including 
contingent liability ceilings.  
(iv)  Prepare policy matrix conditions, time-bound assurances, strategy and 
action plans, performance monitoring methods, and supporting materials 
in standard Asian Development Bank (ADB) format. 
 
B.  International Consultants 
 
b.  Public Finance Specialist: Team Leader (6 person-months) 
 
2.  The consultant will take the following responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Implement  the  technical  assistance  (TA),  including  coordination  and 
supervision of the work of consultants and coordination with consultants 
under  the  advisory  TA  for  Assam  Budget  Procedure  Reform, 
Computerization, and Expenditure Management. 
(ii)  Prepare macroeconomic projections, including alternative scenarios, and 
problem and objective tree analysis for sequenced and linked reforms. 
(iii)  Consult  and  train  stakeholders,  and  prepare  draft  laws,  policies, 
regulations and rules, and manuals on key legal and policy frameworks, 
including on VAT, the debt management policy and fiscal responsibility, 
and budget management framework. 
(iv)  Review the work of other consultants, and identify potential policy and 
institutional constraints, adverse incentives, and procedural bottlenecks 
that could impede reforms. Identify means to address these through a 
coalition of reform interests and window of reform opportunities. 
(v)  Prepare  the  draft  report  and  recommendation  of  the  president  and 
develop a lending modality (e.g., cluster, tranching) for the proposed 
Assam governance and public resource management loan in standard 
ADB format.
